title: [AUR:COMPONENT] Add Backstage (Goose) to Aurora
summary: The Backstage instance developed by the Platform Architecture team needs be deployed as part of the Aurora Platform Charts and serve as the primary front door to the Aurora platform. Aurora must support both a community open source Backstage distribution and a GC Cloud One tailored Backstage, with differences implemented through configuration, plugins, and build parameters rather than separate architectures.

title: [SERVICE:GCSA] Establish curated artifact service across SSC + GoC
summary: Stand up GC Secure Artifacts (GCSA) as the government-wide trusted repository for binaries, container images, and related software artifacts, providing a single, curated source of secure and approved components for all departments. GCSA will centralize artifact storage, provenance, and policy enforcement, reducing duplication across departments and ensuring consistent application of security and compliance controls.

title: [AUR:COMPONENT] Upgrade Istio and Transition to Ambient Mesh
summary: We need to upgrade Istio from version 1.16.x to an Ambient Mesh capable release at version 1.24.x or higher in order to modernize Aurora’s service mesh architecture. The current sidecar based model introduces operational complexity, higher resource overhead, and upgrade risk at scale. Moving to a supported Ambient Mesh release positions Aurora on a forward looking Istio architecture that is actively developed, better aligned with upstream direction, and suitable for long term multi cloud operations.

title: [CSP:PC] Onboard Aurora onto GC Private Cloud
summary: Extend Aurora to the GC Private Cloud (OpenStack) by integrating with the Rancher workflow that provisions RKE2 Kubernetes clusters on demand using OpenTofu, aiming where possible to align with the Azure implementation to minimize context switching. Azure-native services used in Azure, such as Azure Key Vault, will be replaced with Vault in the private cloud.

title: [AUR:COMPONENT] AAD Pod Identity to Workload Identity
summary: Migrate existing AKS configurations from the legacy Azure AD Pod Identity mechanism to the modern Azure Workload Identity model. Azure AD Pod Identity is deprecated and approaching retirement, and continued reliance on it introduces operational risk, limits future platform upgrades, and creates unnecessary complexity in identity management across clusters.

title: [AUR:DOCS] Aurora Platform Documentation
summary: Track the creation and maintenance of high-level Aurora documentation and reference materials. This includes architectural overviews, diagrams, and explanatory content that describe key concepts such as multi-tenancy, Namespace-as-a-Service (NaaS), security boundaries, and traffic isolation within the Aurora platform.

title: [CSP:AZURE] Aurora Platform Charts and Images Are Proxied
summary: The Aurora Platform Charts currently support proxying Helm charts and container images through GC Secure Artifacts (GCSA), but default to consuming public open source repositories directly. While this is suitable for development and experimentation, it does not satisfy enterprise compliance, security, or software supply-chain requirements for production deployments.

title: [AUR:COMMUNITY] Planning and Execution of Aurora Community Meetups
summary: Facilitate the organization, coordination, and delivery of Aurora community meetups to promote collaboration, knowledge sharing, and meaningful engagement among stakeholders. This includes the logistical planning, communication strategies, and content development needed to provide a welcoming, inclusive, and impactful experience for all participants.

title: [CSP:AZURE] Cilium BYOCNI and VNET Integration
summary: Because the cluster uses Cilium as the CNI via BYOCNI on AKS rather than Azure CNI, enabling VNet integration changes Azure’s routing assumptions. Azure applies default VNet routing that conflicts with Cilium’s eBPF-based networking model, which can disrupt connectivity if not explicitly accounted for.

title: [CSP:AZURE] Enhance ESLZ integration with further automation
summary: While much of the process is already automated and both Aurora and the Azure team operate under established SOPs, there are still integration gaps that require tighter coordination. For example, Backstage must reliably capture and validate the input values required by the Azure team, trigger the appropriate requests, and ensure downstream automation, such as repository creation via API, is executed end to end.
